awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Constraining the flux of magma and magmatic CO2 during early-stage rifting in East Africa
awd_abstract_narration:
Identifying and quantifying the key ingredients for rift initiation and evolution is fundamental to our understanding of plate tectonic theory, revealing how extensional plate boundaries initiate and develop in order to break apart continents. Two of these ingredients, magma and magmatic volatiles, play not only a critical role in continent break up, but also the growth of continental crust and atmospheric evolution. Critically, rates of magmatism and related magmatic degassing are poorly constrained for continental rifts on Earth, and thus the primary focus of this study is to quantify the flux of magma and magmatic volatiles during the initial stages of continental rifting. In addition to constraining these fundamental parameters, outcomes of this project will include refining annual estimates of natural carbon dioxide emissions, quantifying rates of magma recharge into hazardous volcanoes, and advancing our understanding of subsurface fluid movement in areas of geothermal energy potential. The outcomes of this project can also inform earthquake models by better constraining processes of fluid movements along faults, potentially leading to advances in earthquake hazard forecasts. 

To answer these questions, new measurements of field-based gas flux and carbon isotopes analyses of magmatic CO2 will be collected along and across the rift axis of the East African Rift. Target areas include the Manyara, Natron, and Magadi rift basins near the Kenya-Tanzania border, which range in age from 1 to 7 Ma. By comparing rift basins of different ages, we will illuminate along-axis changes in volatile degassing at different stages of rift development through time. An important goal is to place these findings in context with existing observations (e.g., geophysical, geochemical, geodetic) of key rifting processes to identify spatial links between volatile flux, tectonic deformation, magma intrusion, and volcanism. Field, geochemical, and geophysical observations will then be compared and contrasted with thermal-petrographic model simulations of tectonic extension and magmatic processes (e.g., intrusion, cooling, crystallization, and degassing). Numerical modeling scenarios will be constrained by, and tested against, the full range of observational datasets in the region, including: (1) newly acquired CO2 data, (2) sub-crustal magma bodies inferred from existing 2-D and 3-D geophysical models, (3) chemistry and phase equilibria of erupted products, (4) thermal state of the crust, and (5) crustal thinning. Comparisons between observations and modeling results will allow us to constrain, for the first time, the plausible range of magma fluxes at various locations and stages of rift development at this type locality for active magmatic rifting.

por.por_cntn:
Magma intrusion and related volatile percolation during continental rifting plays a critical role in the breakup of thick lithosphere, growth of continental crust, and release of greenhouse gases. However, rates and spatial variation in magmatism and related volatile degassing in many magmatic sectors of the East African Rift System (EARS) are poorly constrained. This grant undertook the first study to link the flux and evolution of magmatic volatiles during early-stage continental rifting. The EARS has been identified by GeoPRISMS (Rift Initiation and Evolution) as a high-priority setting to investigate: (1) the mechanisms and consequences of fluid and volatile exchange between the lithosphere and atmosphere, and (2) the time-space evolution of magma and volatile systems during continental rift development. We directly addressed these aims by focusing on the following questions:

1. What is volume of magmatic CO2 emitted from continental rifts in their initiation stages, and the corresponding time- averaged rates of magma emplacement?

2. What are the time-space relationships between seismicity, intrusive magmatism, and CO2 emissions, and their relation to strain localization in early-stage rifts (<10 Ma)?

3. Does the location and flux of magma and volatiles vary as a function of rift maturity?

To address these questions, we made measurements of field-based gas flux and carbon isotopes analyses of magmatic carbon dioxide, both along and across the rift axis. Target areas were the Manyara (1 Ma), Natron (3 Ma), and Magadi basins (7 Ma), which enabled comparison of along-axis changes in volatile degassing at different stages of rift development through time. In this project we related these gas measurements to existing geophysical and geochemical data. The second stage of the project integrated thermal-petrographic modeling that simulates tectonic extension and magmatic processes (e.g., intrusion, cooling, crystallization, and degassing). The numerical modeling scenarios were constrained by, and tested against, the full range of observational datasets in the region, including: (1) our newly acquired CO2 data, (2) sub- crustal magma bodies inferred from existing 2-D and 3-D geophysical models, (3) chemistry and phase equilibria of erupted products, (4) thermal state of the crust, and (5) crustal thinning.

To model the thermal/magmatic evolution of this system: 1) We examined a broad parameter space to better understand the role of varying extension rates, intrusion rates and volatile flux have on the melt residence times and thermal evolution of a rifting system. 2) We developed a depth dependent extensional model to make the results more general to different parts of the African rift and globally. 3) We have implemented forward geophysical models to facilitate comparison of these model results to seismic, magnetotelluric, and gravity data sets. In particular we have worked on incorporating a seismic velocity model into our crustal model which should greatly improve our ability to compare to existing seismic velocity datasets in East Africa. As part of this work we have also worked on improving the modeled petrologic phases from the thermal model which was necessary for more refined estimates of seismic velocity, but may also be useful for future petrologic investigations and comparisons. Finally, 4) we have explored a more refined parameter space with simulations to better understand the volatile flux from specific regions of extension in East Africa, an in particular the Magadi and Natron basins. Part of this work has involved simulations delimiting where and how much carbon dioxide is released in the crust during magmatic intrusion episodes.

Finally, by analyzing diffuse soil carbon dioxide degassing and helium isotopes in spring systems in various rift basins across the EARS, we demonstrated how mantle volatile fluxes from tectonic degassing vary as a function of initial lithospheric conditions and the stage of rift evolution. In the Eastern Branch, we observe a distinct contrast in the flux and source of volatiles at a geophysically-defined cratonic-orogenic boundary, and propose that displacement of cratonic mantle and lithospheric channeling may concentrate deep carbon near cratonic boundaries. Comparative investigations of tectonic carbon dioxide discharges in evolved (e.g. Afar Depression, Ethiopia) and early-stage (<10 Ma Magadi Basin, Kenya) magma-rich basins also reveal how mantle carbon fluxes vary during rift evolution. Specifically, helium isotope data from springs in the Afar Depression support asthenospheric volatile sources (i.e., MORB, plume), whereas in the Magadi basin volatiles are likely sourced from the lithospheric mantle, consistent with geochemical studies constraining zones of mantle melt generation in these regions. We also observed a reduction in the total area and volume of tectonic volatile degassing in evolved rifts corresponding with these evolving melt and volatile sources. As such, we propose that thinning of mantle lithosphere during rift evolution results in a possible order of magnitude reduction in carbon dioxide discharge, which may explain discrepancies observed between carbon dioxide fluxes at continental rifts and ocean-spreading centers.
